title: Abdominal drainage to prevent intraperitoneal abscess after appendectomy for complicated appendicitis
authors: Tang, Y; Liu, J; Bai, G; Cheng, N; Deng, Y; Cheng, Y

response.output:
Is placing a drain (a tube to remove fluid) in the abdomen after surgery for a burst or perforated appendix effective at preventing belly infections (intraperitoneal abscess)?

Key messages
– Using a drain after surgery for a burst or perforated appendix does not reduce belly infections and may increase the risk of death, but the evidence is very uncertain because the studies were small and had design problems.  
– No reliable studies compared different drain types (open versus closed) or looked at the best time to remove a drain.  
– Larger, well‑designed trials are needed to find out whether drains are helpful and safe.

What is complicated appendicitis and why does it matter?  
Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix, a small pouch attached to the large intestine. When the appendix dies (gangrenous) or bursts (perforated), the condition is called complicated appendicitis. This can spread infection into the abdominal cavity (peritonitis) and may lead to painful pockets of pus called intraperitoneal abscesses after surgery. Surgeons remove the appendix (appendectomy) through an open cut or a keyhole (laparoscopic) approach. Because the infection risk is higher, they sometimes place an abdominal drain – a thin tube that helps remove fluid or pus that might collect after the operation.

What did the review aim to find out?  
We wanted to know whether placing an abdominal drain after appendectomy for complicated appendicitis improves outcomes. Specifically we asked: (1) does a drain reduce infections or other complications compared with no drain? (2) do different drain types (open vs closed) give different results? (3) is there an optimal time to remove the drain?

How did we find the evidence?  
We searched medical databases for studies that compared using a drain with not using a drain after appendectomy for complicated appendicitis. We combined the results of similar studies (a meta‑analysis) or described them individually when pooling was not possible. We then rated our confidence in each result using the GRADE system, which grades how certain we are that the evidence reflects the true effect.

What did we find?  
We identified eight studies – five randomized trials and three trials that tried to assign patients in a similar way – involving a total of 739 people (370 received a drain, 369 did not). The studies were done in North America, Asia and Africa between 1973 and 2023 and included both children and adults, most of whom had perforated appendicitis with peritonitis. All participants received antibiotics after open or laparoscopic surgery. The only comparison made was drain versus no drain; no study looked at open versus closed drains or at early versus late drain removal.

What were the main results for 30‑day mortality?  
Seven deaths occurred among people with a drain (7/291) compared with one death among those without a drain (1/290). This suggests that using a drain probably increases the risk of death within 30 days after surgery. For other outcomes – such as intraperitoneal abscess, wound infection, overall complications and length of hospital stay – the evidence is very uncertain.

What are the limitations of the evidence?  
Many studies were small and had a high risk of bias. Participants and clinicians often knew which treatment was given, which can influence results. Not all studies reported every outcome we wanted, and the study populations and methods varied.

How up‑to‑date is this review?  
This review updates the previous Cochrane review and includes evidence up to October 2023.
